Months later, Raicaldo saw the 19-year-old who was driving the Humvee that day.
I seen him at Fort Dix with one of my friends, another soldier in my unit, and we looked at each other, and he goes - he started crying.
He goes, I'm sorry, I'm sorry, because he's seeing - you know, I looked even worse.
I had the cane and everything.
I said - I just grabbed a hold of him, and I hugged him, and I said don't take this home.
I said, it's over right now.
I said there's nothing to be sorry about.
I said all you were trying to do was drive, trying to learn something.
Nobody taught us, nobody showed us how these things flip over.
It's not your fault.
And he just cried and cried.
I held him, and I said you are - not even forgiven - there was nothing to forgive to begin with.
I said I'm fine.
I started cracking jokes.
And he still didn't lighten up.
He still was very sad, like you know?
And then I said by the way, wait until you get my bill.
Then he started laughing.
We get coffee and head to Jones Beach.
He used to swim here every day.
We walk for a bit on the boardwalk.
Raicaldo gets winded.
He has to sit down before we head back to the Plymouth.
The VA has been pushing him to do trauma counseling along with his medical appointments.
He wants to focus first on his body, his back and his infections.
Then, he says, he'll talk about what Iraq did to his mind.

I said well, you know what?
I was afraid to walk, I was afraid to leave the building, I was afraid to cross the street.
Now I'm driving my car.
Can I get over these fears, can I get over this not sleeping?
Yes.
My biggest concern for a guy like me, old school, is the fact that I always had an income coming in.
I don't know who's going to hire me, and I'll tell you right now that's the worst fear than anyone shooting at me is the fact that I'm not working.

Spain's prime minister is expected to visit Dublin next month to learn about the Irish peace process.
Like ETA, the Irish Republican Army used terrorist tactics in its fight to end British rule in Northern Ireland.
The April issue of the Atlantic Monthly provides an in depth look at how British security forces infiltrated the IRA.
Writer Matthew Teague profiles two double agents who navigated a deadly path between appearing loyal to their IRA brethren and secretly working to bring down the organization.
Teague begins his story at Victoria Station in London, where he met one of the double agents known as Kevin Fulton.
He was a spy for the British within the IRA for about a decade and a half.

He was from Northern Ireland but had joined the British Army and they recruited him from there to go back to Northern Ireland to join the IRA, and he rose up through the ranks and became part of a bomb making team.
By day he would build bombs for the IRA and then from time to time he would have meetings with his spy handlers from the British intelligence services.
Sometimes he could sabotage plans and sometimes he couldn't.
Now the other guy you profile is Freddy Scapiticci(ph).
He's the son of Italian immigrants and he's head of what's known in the IRA as the nutting squad.
What was that?

Well, in northern Irish slang the nut is the head, and so the nutting squad, when they found a spy or a snitch, they would nut him by shooting him twice in the brain, and so they were sort of an internal security unit who would comb through the IRA ranks looking for a mole.
And here was this guy in their midst who is a mole.
Right.
I mean it was a brilliant strategic maneuver.

It set him up such that he almost couldn't be discovered because anytime there was a suspicion of double-dealing, it was him that would be reported to so he was able to cover his tracks or finger someone else, whatever he needed to do to keep his cover.
Now, what's intriguing about the stories of both of these men, Scapiticci and Fulton, is how they keep their cover by continuing to kill.
That's what's different about what the British did in Northern Ireland.

Typically you think of a spy as someone who goes out, eavesdrops, gathers information, collects it and then reports back, whereas the British allowed their agents to become part of the organization, the IRA, to become active members and even to rise up to become leaders.
The only difference between these agents and the terrorists that they were working against was that they, you know, called home after a mission.
It opens up a gray area, in particular for the government.
There's this one example where Fulton takes a trip to New York sponsored by his British intelligence handlers but he's going there to actually get bomb technology for the IRA.
